lessonActivities.title: Present Perfect = Your Life Movie Trailer!
lessonActivities.content:
Imagine your life as a movie trailer! Present Perfect shows clips from the past that still matter NOW. I‚Äôve been to Japan ‚Üí experience! I‚Äôve lost my keys ‚Üí still lost!

Form: have/has + past participle

Fun fact: It‚Äôs the tense of adventurers, travelers, and people who say ‚ÄúI‚Äôve done that!‚Äù
lessonActivities.tips: If it affects NOW ‚Üí Present Perfect!

lessonActivities.title: Simple vs Continuous: Result vs Journey!
lessonActivities.content:
Simple = the result (how many?) ‚Üí I‚Äôve written 3 emails.

Continuous = the journey (how long?) ‚Üí I‚Äôve been writing emails all morning.

Live/work/study/teach ‚Üí both OK!

Fun fact: Continuous = you‚Äôre tired from the action. Simple = proud of the result!
examples: I‚Äôve been reading all day. (tired eyes!)
She‚Äôs worked here for 10 years = She‚Äôs been working here for 10 years.
lessonActivities.tips: Ask: How many? ‚Üí Simple. How long? ‚Üí Continuous.

lessonActivities.title: Ever & Never: Your Adventure Passport!
lessonActivities.content:
Stamp your passport! Ever = in your whole life (questions). Never = not even once.

Position: between have/has and verb.

Fun fact: People who say ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never‚Ä¶‚Äù sound mysterious and cool!
lessonActivities.tips: Ever in questions, never in negatives.

lessonActivities.title: For & Since: Time Machine Anchors!
lessonActivities.content:
For = duration (for 2 hours, for 10 years). Since = starting point (since 2015, since Monday).

Use with Present Perfect to show something started in past and continues now.

Fun fact: ‚ÄúSince I was 5‚Äù = you‚Äôre still alive and kicking!
functions: Showing duration from past to now
lessonActivities.tips: For = length. Since = when it started.

lessonActivities.title: Already, Yet, Just, Still: Drama Queens!
lessonActivities.content:
Already = sooner than expected (+). Yet = until now (questions/negatives). Just = seconds ago. Still = continues now (often continuous).

Fun fact: ‚ÄúStill‚Äù with continuous = someone is annoyed!
lessonActivities.tips: Yet ‚Üí end of sentence. Already ‚Üí mid-sentence.

lessonActivities.title: Present Perfect vs Past Simple: Time Detective!
lessonActivities.content:
Present Perfect ‚Üí time period NOT finished (today, this week, in my life). Past Simple ‚Üí finished time (yesterday, last year, in 2019).

If you can answer ‚ÄúWhen?‚Äù, use Past Simple!

Fun fact: Indonesians often use Past Simple for today ‚Üí but in exams, NO!
examples: I‚Äôve seen Avatar 3 times this month. (month not over)
lessonActivities.tips: Today/this week ‚Üí Present Perfect. Yesterday ‚Üí Past Simple.

lessonActivities.title: Stative Verbs: No -ing Allowed!
lessonActivities.content:
Stative verbs = states, not actions ‚Üí NO continuous! Know, like, love, want, need, believe, understand, have (=own), belong, seem, etc.

Wrong: I‚Äôve been knowing him for 10 years. Correct: I‚Äôve known him for 10 years.

Exception: have (action) ‚Üí having dinner = OK!
lessonActivities.tips: If it‚Äôs a feeling or possession ‚Üí no -ing!

lessonActivities.title: Your Turn: Life Story Time!
lessonActivities.content:
Now write about YOUR life using everything: experiences, how long, stative verbs, already/yet, and NO Past Simple for today/this week!

Pro tip: The best stories start with ‚ÄúHave you ever‚Ä¶?‚Äù

writingActivities.question: Life experiences: Write 4 sentences using ever (question) and never with Present Perfect Simple.
How long have you‚Ä¶? Write 5 sentences using for or since + Present Perfect (mix Simple & Continuous).
writingActivities.hint: For = period ‚Üí for 5 years / Since = point ‚Üí since 2020

writingActivities.hint: This week = unfinished time ‚Üí Present Perfect only!

writingActivities.question: Today vs yesterday: Write 3 sentences with today (Present Perfect) + 3 with yesterday (Past Simple).
writingActivities.hint: Today ‚Üí I‚Äôve eaten / Yesterday ‚Üí I ate

writingActivities.question: Your personality & things you own: Write 6 sentences using stative verbs in Present Perfect Simple (NO continuous!).
writingActivities.hint: Wrong: I‚Äôve been knowing‚Ä¶ Correct: I‚Äôve known / I‚Äôve always liked

writingActivities.question: Good news & bad news this month: Write 5 sentences using just, already, and still haven‚Äôt.
writingActivities.hint: I‚Äôve just passed my test! / I still haven‚Äôt found my keys.

writingActivities.question: How long + recent effort: Write 5 sentences ‚Äî 3 with for/since + 2 with lately/recently + Present Perfect Continuous.
writingActivities.hint: I‚Äôve been studying English for 3 years / Lately I‚Äôve been feeling tired

writingActivities.question: Write a short message to a friend you haven‚Äôt seen for ages. Use Present Perfect to talk about changes + since we last met.
writingActivities.hint: Since we last met, I‚Äôve moved house three times!

writingActivities.question: Your biggest achievements so far: Write 6 sentences using Present Perfect Simple + ever or never + one just.
writingActivities.hint: I‚Äôve never failed an exam / I‚Äôve just won a competition!

writingActivities.question: Mixed challenge: Write a diary entry (6‚Äì8 sentences) using: 2 for/since, 1 already/yet, 1 just, 1 Present Perfect Continuous, 1 stative verb correctly.
writingActivities.hint: Today has been crazy! I‚Äôve been running all day‚Ä¶ but I still haven‚Äôt finished‚Ä¶

quizActivities.question: What grammar function does the Present Perfect express in this context?
options: Describing a finished past event with a specific time
quizActivities.hint: The phrase 'been to Japan' with no time marker indicates a life experience. Use Present Perfect for experiences in your life so far.
quizActivities.explanation: Present Perfect is used for life experiences without specifying when they happened. The other options are incorrect: Past Simple would be used with a specific time, and the sentence isn‚Äôt about prediction or directions.

quizActivities.question: Which form shows an action that has a present result?
quizActivities.sentence: I can‚Äôt find my phone! I ____ it.
quizActivities.hint: When the result (still missing) matters now, use Present Perfect. Look for present consequences like frustration or current inability.
quizActivities.explanation: 'Have lost' shows the action happened in the past but the phone is still missing now. 'Lost' (Past Simple) would imply a finished story with no current relevance.

quizActivities.question: What verb form completes this time clause correctly?
quizActivities.sentence: She‚Äôs lived in Jakarta since she ____ university.
quizActivities.hint: Time clauses with 'since' use Past Simple, not Present Perfect, even when the main clause is Present Perfect.
quizActivities.explanation: After 'since', we use Past Simple to mark the starting point of a period that continues to the present. The rule: after 'since', always use Past Simple for completed events.

quizActivities.question: What aspect describes an ongoing activity at a specific past time?
quizActivities.sentence: At 8 p.m. last night, I ____ dinner.
quizActivities.hint: For actions in progress at a specific past time, use Past Continuous (was/were + -ing).
quizActivities.explanation: 'At 8 p.m. last night' indicates a specific moment in the past when the action was ongoing. Past Continuous shows duration in progress at that time.

quizActivities.question: Which shows a prediction based on current evidence?
quizActivities.sentence: Look at those dark clouds! It ____ rain soon.
quizActivities.hint: When you see evidence happening now (dark clouds), use 'be going to' for predictions.
quizActivities.explanation: 'Is going to' is used for predictions based on present evidence. 'Will' is for spontaneous decisions or general predictions without visible signs.

quizActivities.question: What's the best choice for expressing a spontaneous decision?
quizActivities.sentence: The phone is ringing! I ____ it.
quizActivities.hint: For instant decisions made at the moment of speaking, use 'will'.
quizActivities.explanation: 'I‚Äôll answer' shows a decision made right now. 'Be going to' would imply prior intention, which doesn‚Äôt fit a sudden ring.

quizActivities.question: Choose the correct tenses for this complex sentence:
quizActivities.sentence: I ____ three reports today, so when I ____ home, I ____ relax.
quizActivities.hint: Use Present Perfect for unfinished time (today), Present Simple in time clauses (when I get), and 'will' for future result.
quizActivities.explanation: This requires understanding multiple rules: Present Perfect for 'today' (not finished), Present Simple after 'when' for future time clauses, and 'will' for the intended future result. Pay attention to time reference and clause structure.

quizActivities.question: What aspect is used for actions in progress at a specific future time?
quizActivities.sentence: At 9 p.m. tomorrow, we ____ watch the concert live.
quizActivities.hint: Use Future Continuous (will be + -ing) for actions in progress at a specific future time.
quizActivities.explanation: Future Continuous emphasizes the ongoing nature of the action at 9 p.m. tomorrow. It shows the action will be in progress, not just scheduled.

quizActivities.question: Which structure correctly expresses a life experience with 'ever'?
quizActivities.hint: 'Ever' in questions about life experiences requires Present Perfect. Use 'have/has + past participle'.
quizActivities.explanation: The key difference: Present Perfect is for experiences in your whole life; Past Simple is for specific past times. Here, 'ever' signals a life-time question, so 'Have you ever tried' is correct.

quizActivities.question: What negative form is correct for Present Perfect?
quizActivities.hint: Negative Present Perfect uses 'has/have + not + past participle'. Watch out for using the wrong verb form (e.g., 'went' instead of 'been').
quizActivities.explanation: To form negatives in Present Perfect, use 'has/have + not + past participle'. Common error: using the base form or simple past instead of the past participle ('been', not 'went').

quizActivities.question: Which question form is grammatically correct for Present Perfect?
quizActivities.hint: Question word order: auxiliary (have/has) + subject + past participle + complement.
quizActivities.explanation: Questions in Present Perfect follow this pattern: 'Have/Has + subject + past participle...'. The auxiliary 'have' comes before the subject 'you'.

quizActivities.question: Advanced: What's the most precise structure for emphasizing effort over result?
quizActivities.sentence: My eyes hurt‚ÄîI ____ emails all morning.
quizActivities.hint: The subtle difference is focus: continuous emphasizes duration and effort; simple emphasizes quantity. 'Eyes hurt' indicates tiredness from ongoing action.
quizActivities.explanation: While 'I‚Äôve written emails' is grammatically possible, 'I‚Äôve been writing emails' is more precise here because it explains the cause of tired eyes‚Äîongoing effort. This shows the Present Perfect Continuous for emphasis on process.

quizActivities.question: Identify the error in this sentence:
quizActivities.hint: Look for stative verbs. Remember: 'know' is a state, not an action‚Äîno continuous form!
quizActivities.explanation: The error is using continuous with a stative verb. 'Know' describes a state, so it cannot be used in continuous tenses. The correct form is 'I‚Äôve known her since 2015' because it shows a relationship continuing from past to present.

quizActivities.question: Which structure best expresses a recent completed action with 'just'?
quizActivities.sentence: He ____ arrived‚Äîhe‚Äôs still catching his breath!
quizActivities.hint: Consider the context clue: 'still catching breath' shows very recent action. Present Perfect with 'just' emphasizes immediacy.
quizActivities.explanation: Both 'just arrived' (Past Simple) and '‚Äôs just arrived' are grammatically possible, but '‚Äôs just arrived' (Present Perfect) is best because it connects the recent past action to the present state (breathlessness).

quizActivities.question: Complete the sequence with the correct structures:
quizActivities.sentence: First, I ____ my keys. Then, when I ____ them, I ____ calm again.
options: have lost / have found / have felt
quizActivities.hint: Use Past Simple for the first action, Past Simple in the time clause, and Past Simple for the result‚Äîall are completed past events.
quizActivities.explanation: This sequence requires: Past Simple for 'lost' (completed past action), Past Simple after 'when' (time clause for completed past), and Past Simple for 'felt' (result in the past). No connection to the present is implied.
